title: 111_hr2076
content: The "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009" aims to protect Federal lands along the US-Mexico border from unauthorized immigration, smuggling, and border enforcement activities. It ensures that all necessary operations for border security are carried out effectively. The Act aims to protect Federal lands along the US-Mexico border from unauthorized immigration, smuggling, and border enforcement activities. It defines key terms and outlines the responsibilities of various Secretaries in ensuring border security. The Act requires the Secretaries of various departments to develop a border protection strategy for the US international land borders by September 30, 2009. Components of the strategy include a comparative analysis of operational control levels achievable through different security measures like fencing, barriers, and additional Border Patrol agents. The border protection strategy for US international land borders includes assessing infrastructure and security measures such as pedestrian fencing, vehicle barriers, additional Border Patrol agents, natural barriers, and advanced technology like unmanned aerial vehicles for surveillance and response analysis in difficult terrain. The border protection strategy for US international land borders includes advanced technologies and systems for surveillance, information integration, and response analysis in difficult terrain. It also involves regional variations in border security methodologies, cooperation with Mexico and Canada for detecting unauthorized crossings, and removal of obstructive vegetation. A comprehensive cost analysis is also conducted. The comprehensive cost analysis of security measures includes assessing land acquisition, construction, maintenance, contractor, management, and overhead costs, as well as impacts on wildlife, habitat, and hydrology over 25 years. The impacts on wildlife, habitat, natural communities, and hydrology along the border, including costs of mitigating adverse effects and restoring wildlife migration corridors. The curr_chunk discusses the replacement or restoration of severed wildlife migration corridors with protected corridors of equivalent biological functionality, as determined by relevant authorities. It also includes a comprehensive compilation of fiscal investments in acquiring or managing lands for conservation purposes near the US borders. The curr_chunk discusses the conservation of state, local, and private lands and waters near the US borders managed for conservation purposes in various federal jurisdictions. The curr_chunk discusses strategic border security management recommendations based on comparative security, cost-benefit analysis, and protection of investments in public lands. Required training for natural resource protection is also highlighted. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Secretary concerned, shall provide natural resource protection and cultural resource training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure and patrolling land along the U.S. border. The Secretary, in cooperation with relevant tribal governments, provides training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure and patrolling tribal lands. Training focuses on achieving border security objectives while minimizing adverse impacts on natural and cultural resources. SEC. 5. ACTIONS TO GAIN OPERATIONAL CONTROL OF THE INTERNATIONAL LAND BORDERS OF THE UNITED STATES. Amendment to improve operational control of the border. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to gain operational control of the international land borders of the United States, prioritizing the use of various border enforcement techniques. Consultation with various government agencies and stakeholders is necessary to minimize the impact on the environment and communities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must work with other government agencies, stakeholders, and private property owners to minimize the impact on the environment and communities near proposed action sites. This subsection does not create or negate any rights of action, affect eminent domain laws, or waive other applicable laws. The Secretary of Homeland Security is not required to install certain resources along the international border if they are not the most effective means to achieve operational control or if the costs and impacts outweigh the benefits. This is subject to certain preconditions. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consider whether the costs and impacts of installing resources along the border outweigh the benefits before proceeding with any construction. This is subject to specific preconditions, including a 90-day waiting period after submitting the border protection strategy to Congress. SEC. 6. BORDERLANDS MONITORING AND MITIGATION. The Secretary, in consultation with various agencies, must develop a monitoring and mitigation plan for the ecological impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan includes measures to preserve wildlife habitats, migration corridors, and address invasive species. The mitigation plan for ecological impacts of border security infrastructure includes ensuring functional connectivity between habitats, addressing invasive species control, maintaining hydrological functionality, incorporating adaptive management, and protecting cultural and historical resources. The Secretary has the authority to implement this plan on various lands near international borders. The Secretary has the authority to carry out a mitigation plan on Federal, State, local, tribal, or private lands near international borders, regardless of ownership. Activities must be done in consultation with the landowner or responsible entity. The Secretary of Homeland Security can transfer funds to other agencies for expenditure on programs, including international ones. The Secretary of Homeland Security may transfer funds to other Federal agencies for conservation activities on non-Federal lands and mitigation activities on Federal lands. Transferred funds are exempt from reprogramming requirements. The Secretary of Homeland Security can use funds for conservation and mitigation activities on non-Federal and Federal lands. Funds transferred are exempt from reprogramming requirements. Additionally, funds appropriated for border security can be used to develop and implement the required mitigation plan.
